title: verify
text:
cli.verify(dataset_name=None, env='base')
The tdda verify command is used to validate pandas dataframes, against a constraints specification.











Name
Type
Description
Default




dataset_name
Optional[str]
Optional catalog name for the pandas dataset. If not specified, verify will check constraints for every pandas dataset in the catalog
None


env
Optional[str]
Which conf//tdda folder to read constraints from
'base'

title: discover
text:
cli.discover(dataset_name=None, env=DEFAULT_ENV_TDDA, overwrite=None)
The tdda discover command generates constraints for data, and saves the generated constraints as a yaml file.











Name
Type
Description
Default




dataset_name
Optional[str]
Optional catalog name for the pandas dataset. If not specified, discover will write constraints for every pandas dataset in the catalog
None


env
Optional[str]
Which conf//tdda folder to write the constraints to
DEFAULT_ENV_TDDA


overwrite
Optional[bool]
If a constraints file exists, the overwrite flag will overwrite the file.
None






kedro discover

title: detect
text:
cli.detect(dataset_name=None, env='base', target_dir='./tdda_detect')
The tdda detect command is used to detect anomalies on data, by checking pandas dataframes against specified constraints.











Name
Type
Description
Default




dataset_name
Optional[str]
Optional catalog name for the pandas dataset. If not specified, discover will write constraints for every pandas dataset in the catalog
None


env
Optional[str]
Which conf//tdda folder to read constraints from
'base'


target_dir
Optional[str]
Which directory to write detect (.csv) files to
'./tdda_detect'






kedro discover

title: kedro-tdda
text:
This plugin extends kedro with a lightweight data validation tool: tdda. The tdda package enables you to discover constraints from data, validate new data and detect anomalies. Check the tdda website for more info.
This kedro plugin is limited to itâ€™s constraints API and alike tdda only supports pandas datasets. The plugin includes a CLI interface and dataset hooks
For more extensive needs, please check kedro_pandera


You can install the package like so
pip install git+https://github.com/sinanpl/kedro_tdda





The plugin currently uses the constraints API of tdda. The available commands are

discover: infer constraints for a dataset and write to yaml. Constraints are inferred by field. Examples are:

type: one of int, real, bool, string or date
min: minimum allowed value,
max: maximum allowed value,
min_length: minimum allowed string length (for string fields),
max_length: maximum allowed string length (for string fields),
max_nulls: maximum number of null values allowed,
sign: one of positive, negative, non-positive, non-negative,
no_duplicates: true if the field values must be unique,
values: list of distinct allowed values,
rex: list of regular expressions, to cover all cases

verify: verify if the dataset - after being updated - respects the constraints.
detect: write a csv records file with deviating rows

kedro tdda discover -h
Options:
  -d, --dataset TEXT  The name of the pandas catalog entry for which
                      constraints be inferred.
  -e, --env TEXT      The kedro environment where the dataset to retrieve is
                      available. Default to 'base'
  -o, --overwrite     Boolean indicator for overwriting an existing tdda
                      constrains yml specification
  -h, --help          Show this message and exit.```



The TddaHooks() will verify a catalog dataset after loading if there is a contraints definition. This hook is automatically registered after installation and can be disabled by updating DISABLE_HOOKS_FOR_PLUGINS in the settings.py of your kedro project
DISABLE_HOOKS_FOR_PLUGINS = ("kedro_tdda",)

title: kedro-tdda
text:
You can install the package like so
pip install git+https://github.com/sinanpl/kedro_tdda

title: kedro-tdda
text:
The plugin currently uses the constraints API of tdda. The available commands are

discover: infer constraints for a dataset and write to yaml. Constraints are inferred by field. Examples are:

type: one of int, real, bool, string or date
min: minimum allowed value,
max: maximum allowed value,
min_length: minimum allowed string length (for string fields),
max_length: maximum allowed string length (for string fields),
max_nulls: maximum number of null values allowed,
sign: one of positive, negative, non-positive, non-negative,
no_duplicates: true if the field values must be unique,
values: list of distinct allowed values,
rex: list of regular expressions, to cover all cases

verify: verify if the dataset - after being updated - respects the constraints.
detect: write a csv records file with deviating rows

kedro tdda discover -h
Options:
  -d, --dataset TEXT  The name of the pandas catalog entry for which
                      constraints be inferred.
  -e, --env TEXT      The kedro environment where the dataset to retrieve is
                      available. Default to 'base'
  -o, --overwrite     Boolean indicator for overwriting an existing tdda
                      constrains yml specification
  -h, --help          Show this message and exit.```



The TddaHooks() will verify a catalog dataset after loading if there is a contraints definition. This hook is automatically registered after installation and can be disabled by updating DISABLE_HOOKS_FOR_PLUGINS in the settings.py of your kedro project
DISABLE_HOOKS_FOR_PLUGINS = ("kedro_tdda",)

title: Function reference
text:
discover
The tdda discover command generates constraints for data,


verify
The tdda verify command is used to validate pandas dataframes,


detect
The tdda detect command is used to detect anomalies on data,









TddaHooks

title: Function reference
text:
discover
The tdda discover command generates constraints for data,


verify
The tdda verify command is used to validate pandas dataframes,


detect
The tdda detect command is used to detect anomalies on data,

title: TddaHooks
text:
hooks.TddaHooks()





Name
Description




after_context_created
After the KedroContext is created, the config loader is


after_dataset_loaded
This dataset hook will run tdda verify on each dataset





hooks.TddaHooks.after_context_created(context)
After the KedroContext is created, the config loader is modified to include the pattern tdda. This will load tdda specification that match the regex pattern. Subsequently, constraints specifications are saved for furhter use with dataset hooks.



hooks.TddaHooks.after_dataset_loaded(dataset_name, data)
This dataset hook will run tdda verify on each dataset that has a constraint specification

After the KedroContext is created, the config loader is modified to include the pattern tdda. This will load tdda specification that match the regex pattern. Subsequently, constraints specifications are saved for furhter use with dataset hooks.



hooks.TddaHooks.after_dataset_loaded(dataset_name, data)
This dataset hook will run tdda verify on each dataset that has a constraint specification
